greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Least multiple of n whose sum of divisors is divisible by n.
comment: See A227470(n) for the sequence a(n)/n. If n = prime(i) is a prime then A097018 gives the answer: a(n) = n*A097018(i). One can show that a(n) always exists - see A227470 for the proof. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, May 01 2016
link: R. J. Mathar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
example: For n = 2, a(2) = 6 because it is the smallest number divisible by 2 whose sum of divisors (12) is also divisible by 2; 3 and 5 are not divisible by 2 and the sum of divisors of 2 and 4 is 3 and 7, hence also not divisible by 2.
mathematica: A272349 = {}; Do[k = n; While[!(Divisible[k, n] && Divisible[DivisorSigma[1, k], n]), k++]; AppendTo[A272349, k], {n, 65}]; A272349
program: (PARI) a(n)=my(k=n); while(sigma(k)%n,k+=n); k \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Apr 28 2016
xref: Cf. A000203, A097018 (if n is a prime), A227470.
results.author: _Waldemar Puszkarz_, Apr 26 2016
